facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated June 22, 1961, of the Second Labour Court, West Bengal in Case No. 97/33A of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated June 22, 1961, of the Second Labour Court, West Bengal in Case No. 97/33A of 1960.

facts.text: Charge-sheet was issued to the appellant on April 23, 1960 under the signature of the Station Manager of the respondent-company.

anchor.surface_text: A charge-sheet was issued to the appe- llant on April 23, 1960 under the signature of the Station Manager of the respondent-company.

facts.text: The charge-sheet contained two charges of gross dereliction of duty: mistakes in the preparation of a load-sheet on one day and a balance chart on another day, which mistakes might have led to a serious accident to the aircraft.

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet companytained two charges of gross dereliction of duty inasmuch as the appellant. had made mistakes in the preparation of a load-sheet on one day and a balance chart on another day, which mistakes might have led to a serious accident to the aircraft.

facts.text: Appellant gave his reply to the charge-sheet on April 26 1960 in which he admitted the mistakes that had been made.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant gave his reply to the chargesheet on April 26 1960 in which he admitted the mistakes that had been made.

facts.text: Appellant contended that he was over-worked and that it was the duty of others also to check the load-sheet and balance chart prepared by him.

anchor.surface_text: He, however., companytended that he was over-worked and further that it was the duty of others also to check the load-sheet and balance chart prepared by him.

facts.text: 9th May 1960 was fixed for inquiry by the Station Manager.

anchor.surface_text: 9th May 1960 was fixed for inquiry by the Station Manager.

facts.text: Appellant objected to the inquiry being held by Station Manager on the ground that the Station Manager was biased against him on account of the evidence which he had given against the Station Manager in a customs case.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant objected to the inquiry being held by Station Manager on the ground that the Station Manager was biased against him on account of the evidence which he had given against the Station Manager in a customs case which was partly responsi- ble for the infliction of a fine on the Station Manager.

facts.text: Appellant's objection was over-ruled and the inquiry was held by the Station Manager and completed on May 10, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: His objection was however over-ruled and the inquiry was held by the Station Manager and companypleted on May 10, 1960.

facts.text: Station Manager forwarded his findings and recommendations to the Regional Representative of the respondent-company.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter it appears that the Station Manager forwarded his findings and recommendations to the Regional Representative of the respondent-company.

facts.text: Appellant was dismissed on May 28, 1960 by the Regional Representative.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was dismissed on May 28, 1960 by the Regional Representative

facts.text: The order of dismissal provided for payment of one months wages to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the order of dismissal provided for payment of one months wages to the appellant and also stated that an application was being made before the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, for approval of the action taken, apparently as some industrial dispute was pending before that tribunal.

facts.text: Order of dismissal was communicated to the appellant on May 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the order of dismissal was companymunicated to the appellant on May 30,

facts.text: One months wages were tendered to the appellant on May 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: and one months wages were also tendered to him.

facts.text: Respondent filed an application before the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, seeking approval of the action on the same day (May 30, 1960).

anchor.surface_text: The same day the respondent filed an application before the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, seeking approval of the action.

facts.text: Appellant made an application under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act on June 3, 1960, challenging the legality of the action taken.

anchor.surface_text: On June 3, 1960, the appellant made an application under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act NO.XIV of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , challenging the legality of the action taken on a large number of grounds.

facts.text: Labour Court held that the dismissal of the appellant was justified and accorded approval.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court held that the dismissal of the appellant was justified and therefore accorded approval for such dismissal.

facts.text: Labour Court held that the application under s. 33(2)(b) was validly made even though made after the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: In particular, dealing with the various points raised on behalf of the appellant, the Labour Court held that the application under s. 33  2   b  of the Act was validly made even though it had been made after the order of dismissal had been passed.

facts.text: Labour Court held that the case was not covered by s. 33(1) and it was not necessary to obtain previous permission before dismissing the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the case was number companyered by s. 33  1  of the Act and it was number necessary to obtain the precious permission of the tribunal before dismissing the appellant.

facts.text: Labour Court held that the appellant was not a protected workman.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the appellant was number a protected workman.

facts.text: Appellant contended that Station Manager was biased, violating principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Further as to the charge that the Station Manager was biased and therefore there was violation of the principles of natural justice,

facts.text: Labour Court noted contention of bias could not be brushed aside lightly but proceeded to decide on evidence adduced.

anchor.surface_text: the Labour Court was of the view that the companytention of the appellant that the Station Manager was biased against him because of the evidence he had given in the customs case companyld number be brushed aside lightly. But it went on to hold that even if there was some violation of the principles of natural justice

facts.text: Appellant admitted the two mistakes which were the basis of the charge.

anchor.surface_text: It pointed out that the appellant had admitted the two mistakes which were the basis of the charge.

facts.text: Labour Court held that the mistakes were of a serious nature which might have resulted in an accident to the aircraft.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the mistakes were of a serious nature which might have resulted in an accident to the aircraft.

facts.text: Fact that other people were also responsible for checking would not mitigate the mistakes committed by the appellant who was primarily responsible.

anchor.surface_text: It said that the fact that other people were also responsible for checking loadsheets and balance-charts would number mitigate the mistakes companymitted by the appellant who was primarily responsible for preparing them.

facts.text: Labour Court repelled the charge of victimisation on account of the delay in giving the charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: It also repelled the charge of victimisation raised on behalf of the appellant on account of the delay in giving him the charge- sheet.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the application under s. 33(2)(b) was in accordance with the proviso.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we are of opinion that the Labour Court was right in holding that the application under s. 33  2   b  was in accordance with the proviso to that section and was properly made.

facts.text: Labour Court finding that appellant was not a protected workman is conclusive.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the question whether a particular workman is a protected workman or number is a question of fact, and the finding of the Labour Court on such a question will generally be accepted by this Court as companyclusive.

facts.text: Station Manager came to know about the mistakes only a few days before the charge-sheet was given, though mistakes committed in January and March.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court has pointed out that the plea of victimisation on the ground that there was some delay in giving the charge-sheet to the appellant cannot be sustained, because the Station Manager came to know about the mistakes only a few days before the charge-sheet was given, though the mistakes had actually been companymitted in January and March,

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in this appeal and it is hereby dismissed.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated June 22, 1961, of the Second Labour Court, West Bengal in Case No. 97/33A of 1960.

On June 3, 1960, the appellant made an application under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act NO.XIV of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , challenging the legality of the action taken on a large number of grounds.

holdings.text: The application under s. 33(2)(b) was in accordance with the proviso to that section and was properly made.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we are of opinion that the Labour Court was right in holding that the application under s. 33  2   b  was in accordance with the proviso to that section and was properly made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso contemplates dismissal, payment of wages, and application as simultaneous parts of same transaction; here order passed May 28, communicated May 30 with wages tendered and application filed same day.

holdings.text: The finding that the appellant was not a protected workman is conclusive as it is a question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the question whether a particular workman is a protected workman or number is a question of fact, and the finding of the Labour Court on such a question will generally be accepted by this Court as companyclusive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Whether workman protected is question of fact; Labour Court finding accepted as conclusive; no evidence of employer recognition as required by rules.

holdings.text: Previous permission under s.33(3) not necessary as appellant not protected workman.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence therefore of any evidence as to recognition, the Labour Court rightly held that the appellant was number a protected workman and therefore previous permission under s. 33  3  of the Act would number be necessary before his dismissal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from not being protected workman; s.33(1) and (3) apply only to protected workmen.

holdings.text: Even if domestic inquiry defective due to bias violating natural justice, tribunal can consider propriety of dismissal on merits and grant approval if justified.

anchor.surface_text: It is number well settled by a number of decisions of this Court that it is open to the tribunal to go into the propriety of an order of dismissal itself, when there is a defect in the domestic inquiry. In these circumstances even if it be held that the Station Manager was biased...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled by precedents like Phulbari Tea Estate; tribunal entitled to appraise evidence afresh.

holdings.text: Tribunal can go into propriety of dismissal order when defect in domestic inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It is number well settled by a number of decisions of this Court that it is open to the tribunal to go into the propriety of an order of dismissal itself, when there is a defect in the domestic inquiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled by number of this Court's decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court has pointed out that the plea of victimisation on the ground that there was some delay in giving the charge-sheet to the appellant cannot be sustained, because the Station Manager came to know about the mistakes only a few days before the charge-sheet was given...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delay explained by late discovery; mistakes admitted; no reason to differ from Labour Court finding of fact.

holdings.text: In s.33(2)(b) proceedings with defective inquiry, if tribunal finds dismissal justified on evidence, approval relates back to date of employer's dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: the Labour Court has only to see whether there was a prima facie case for dismissal, and whether the employer had come to the bona fide conclusion that the employee was guilty of misconduct... its approval of the order of dismissal made by the employer in a defective inquiry would still relate back to the date when the order was made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Sasa Musa (no inquiry or conclusion); here inquiry held (defective), dismissal ordered, justified on evidence; approval validates from original date.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in this appeal and it is hereby dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; Labour Court correctly approved action.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection the Labour Court relied on the decision of this Court in Phulbari Tea Estate Its workmen 1 . The Labour Court then went in-to the evidence tendered before it. It pointed out that the appellant had admitted the two mistakes which were the basis of the charge.

precedents.case_name: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Even if there is violation of principles of natural justice in domestic inquiry due to bias, the tribunal can consider the evidence adduced before it to decide if the action is justified

precedents.citation: Straw Board Manufacturing Co. Limited, Saharanpur v. Govind 2

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in the Straw Board Manufacturing Co. Limited, Saharanpur v. Govind 2 . This Court has held in 1 1960 1 S.C.R. 32, 2 1962 Supp. 8 S.C.R. 618 that case that the proviso to s.33 2 b contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, i dismissal or discharges ii payment of wages, and iii making of an application for approval, to be simultaneous

precedents.case_name: Straw Board Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Govind
precedents.cited_proposition: Proviso to s.33(2)(b) requires dismissal/discharge, payment of one month's wages, and application for approval to be simultaneous and part of the same transaction
precedents.cited_holding: the proviso to s.33 2 b contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, i dismissal or discharges ii payment of wages, and iii making of an application for approval, to be simultaneous and to be part of the same transaction

anchor.surface_text: the Labour Court would be entitled to go into the question whether the dismissal was justified on the evidence led before it and this is exactly what the Labour Court did relying on the judgment of this Court in Phulbari Tea Estate 1 . The contention therefore on behalf of the appellant that the Labour Court was not entitled to go into the question whether the dismissal was justified once it held that the domestic inquiry was defective, must be rejected.

precedents.case_name: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal can go into propriety of dismissal order itself when there is defect in domestic inquiry

precedents.citation: Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works P Ltd. v. Shobrati Khan, 1

anchor.surface_text: Finally it is urged that as the domestic inquiry was defective, there could be no approval of the action taken in consequence of such an inquiry and the Labour Court even if it held that the dismissal was justified should have ordered the dismissal from the date its award would become operative. In this connection reliance was placed on the decision of this Court in Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works P Ltd. v. Shobrati Khan, 1 , where the following observations occur at p. 845

precedents.case_name: M/s Sasa Musa Sugar Works (P) Ltd. v. Shobrati Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: Where no inquiry held and s.33 proceedings convert into inquiry, management bound to pay wages till case for dismissal made out
precedents.cited_holding: as the management held no inquiry after suspending the workmen and proceedings under s. 33 were practically converted into the inquiry which normally the management should have held before applying to the Industrial Tribunal, the management is bound to pay the wages of the workmen till a case for dismissal was made out in the proceedings under s. 33

precedents.citation: Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: The matter would have been different if in that case an inquiry had been held and the employer had come, to the conclusion that dismissal was the proper punishment and then 1 1959 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 719. had applied under s. 33 1 for permission to dismiss. In those circumstances the permission would have related back to the date when the employer came to the conclusion after. an inquiry that dismissal was the proper punishment and had applied for removal of the ban by an application under s. 33 1 see the Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh 1

precedents.case_name: Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Permission under s.33(1) relates back to date when employer concluded after inquiry that dismissal proper and applied

precedents.citation: Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Companys case 2

anchor.surface_text: The observations in Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Companys case 2 , on which the appellant relies apply only to a case where the employer had neither dismissed the employee nor had come to the conclusion that a case for dismissal had been made out.

precedents.case_name: M/s Sasa Musa Sugar Works (P) Ltd. v. Shobrati Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: Observations apply only where no prior dismissal or conclusion for dismissal by employer

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in this appeal and it is hereby dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed, upholding the Labour Court's approval of the appellant's dismissal.
